replication_study.hypothesis: Women (female==1) will report higher worry about COVID-19 than men (female==0), operationalized as a higher mean on mh_anxiety_1 (Likert 1–5), and a higher proportion agreeing (mh_anxiety_1 in {4,5}).

data_plan.source_type: Online survey dataset (CSV) from OSF-linked GitHub repository
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Single cross-section; respondents with CountryofLiving == Germany; records with gender != 3 per script filter
data_plan.sample_size: To be computed after excluding gender==3 and missing mh_anxiety_1; report N_total, N_female, N_male
data_plan.access_details: Provided locally at /app/data/original/4/python/replication_data/data_gerhold.csv; original provenance referenced in R script (GitHub URL to CSV).

qualification.explanation: The dataset contains the necessary variables to test the focal gender difference in COVID worry (mh_anxiety_1; gender/female). It is collected under similar conditions (online survey of adults in Germany) and thus can serve as a high-fidelity independent test of the effect.
qualification.similarity_to_original: Original: Online survey of German adults, Likert items on worry about COVID-19 with gender comparisons (post_registration.json: source, timing Mar 19–23, 2020; study_type Observational; women higher than men on worry). Replication dataset: Columns include mh_anxiety_1, gender, female, CountryofLiving=Germany (replication_data/data_gerhold.csv; R script Gerhold_covid_Azg9_0948_final.R uses these variables), suggesting comparable constructs and population.
qualification.deviation_from_original: Original data timing and panel provider are specific (post_registration.json). The replication CSV originates from a different project (Gerhold_covid_Azg9_0948) and may represent a different sample and collection period; it includes weights (weight_sample, weight_new) not documented in the original summary. The coding of gender differs (gender coded 1/2/3 with female indicator provided), and the item wording is inferred by variable name rather than verified in the original questionnaire.

data_plan.notes: Variables present: ['CountryofLiving','gender','mh_anxiety_1','mh_anxiety_3','weight_sample','weight_new','female']. The R script filters out gender==3 and uses mh_anxiety_1 and mh_anxiety_3 for t-tests. We will confirm value ranges (1–5) and define 'agree' as 4 or 5 to align with original. We will compute weighted and unweighted estimates; primary replication will be unweighted unless original specifies weighting.

planned_method.steps: 1) Load /app/data/original/4/python/replication_data/data_gerhold.csv. 2) Exclude observations with gender==3 and missing mh_anxiety_1. 3) Define groups female==1 vs female==0. 4) Compute group means of mh_anxiety_1 and two-sample t-test (equal variances if F-test p>0.05; otherwise Welch). 5) Compute proportion agreeing (mh_anxiety_1 in {4,5}) by gender and difference in proportions with z-test and p-value. 6) Optionally compute Cohen's d for mean difference. 7) Sensitivity: replicate with weights (if applicable). 8) Report N by group and descriptive stats.
planned_method.models: Two-sample t-test for mean difference in Likert scores; test of difference in proportions (two-proportion z-test) for agree rates; optional variance homogeneity (F-test) and effect size (Cohen's d).
planned_method.outcome_variable: mh_anxiety_1: Likert response for worry/anxiety about COVID-19 (assumed 1–5).
planned_method.independent_variables: female (1=female, 0=male); gender (original coding 1/2/3, used only for exclusion).
planned_method.control_variables: None (bivariate comparison as in original claim).
planned_method.tools_software: Python 3.10+ with pandas, numpy, scipy, statsmodels for tests; optional pingouin for effect sizes (or manual computation).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Mean difference in mh_anxiety_1 (female - male); Proportion difference in agree (female - male); Cohen's d.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: Two-sample t-test (equal variances conditional on F-test); Two-proportion z-test; Levene's or F-test for homoscedasticity.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion for missing mh_anxiety_1 or female; exclude gender==3 per original R script.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Single focal outcome; no multiple-testing adjustment. Exploratory results (mh_anxiety_3) clearly labeled if reported.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Two-sided alpha=0.05. Expect direction female > male as per hypothesis. Report effect size and 95% CI when available.

files.Gerhold_covid_Azg9_0948_final.R: Original R script performing variance tests and t-tests on mh_anxiety_1 and mh_anxiety_3 by gender, filtering out gender==3, and computing Cohen's d.
files.Gerhold_covid_Azg9_0948_final__py.py: Python translation to run the same analysis on /app/data/original/4/python/replication_data/data_gerhold.csv, ensure all IO under /app/data, and output summary tables and test results to /app/data/replication_outputs.

codebase.notes: All data IO will use /app/data paths. We will not modify the original CSV. Outputs (CSV/JSON summaries) will be saved in /app/data/replication_outputs. Dependencies pinned in Docker. If the original R used psych::cohen.d, in Python we compute Cohen’s d manually or via pingouin; prefer manual to minimize dependencies.

analysis.instructions: Run the Python script Gerhold_covid_Azg9_0948_final__py.py. It will load /app/data/original/4/python/replication_data/data_gerhold.csv, filter gender!=3, compute group means, t-tests, agree proportions and z-test, optional weighted sensitivity, and write outputs to /app/data/replication_outputs (text/CSV).
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare direction and significance against original: women > men, p<0.05 for means and/or agree proportions. Report differences in effect sizes (Cohen's d) and percentage-point differences relative to original (68.2% vs 55.7%, Δ=12.5 pp).
